report_title: Healthcare and Social Assistance in the US
executive_summary: Demographic and economic factors are the driving forces behind rising healthcare spending in the US. The population's medical needs are expanding the oldest demographic's consumption of medical services. At the same time, growing incomes and broader insurance coverage facilitate access to healthcare providers. Increasing healthcare spending was abruptly disrupted by the pandemic, exposing healthcare and social assistance providers to unprecedented financial and operational pressures. Though pandemic concerns have alleviated, the long-term effects of it continue to shape every corner of the health sector. Still, revenue has been expanding at a CAGR of 0.7% to an estimated $3.6 trillion over the past five years, with revenue rising an expected 0.3% in 2024.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Demographic Trends Shape the Healthcare Landscape
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Economic and demographic forces have fueled rising spending on healthcare and social assistance services in recent years. The older population's expanding medical needs as they age are the primary force behind higher healthcare spending. Broader insurance coverage has also facilitated access to healthcare services.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Healthcare Providers Grapple With Persistent Workforce Shortages
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: COVID-19 exacerbated labor shortages that had existed prior to the onset of the pandemic. In 2024, healthcare facilities are struggling to attract and retain employees from a smaller employee pool as burnt-out healthcare staff quit, retire or jump to higher-paying positions. Nursing shortages have been straining healthcare providers the most. While hiring challenges will weigh heavily on healthcare providers through 2024, other cost pressures will also strain their financial health.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: The Pandemic Accelerated Existing Consolidation Trends in Healthcare
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Larger health systems eye acquisitions to create economies of scale, lower costs and gain negotiating power. The pandemic accelerated the rising consolidation activity that had been occurring in recent years. Independent (often small or rural) practices risking service eliminations or closure have been targets of acquisitions.

The dramatic rise in the adoption of telemedicine in 2020 has fallen from its pandemic high but is still more integral to healthcare delivery in 2024 than pre-COVID, especially for providers offering mental health treatment.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Digital Tools Adoption to Streamline Operations
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: The challenges impacting healthcare providers are also expediting the adoption of other digital tools (AI, patient engagement products, data analytics) to streamline operations and produce cost savings.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Social Assistance Providers Fill in the Gaps as Pandemic-Era Benefits End
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: The pandemic highlighted societal inequities. Social assistance providers have had an outsized role in addressing these inequities since the COVID-19 pandemic subsided. Pandemic relief funding that cushioned savings accounts and lifted many out of poverty ended between 2022 and 2023, with exact end dates varying between states. As benefits disappeared, millions turned to social assistance providers for help with housing, food assistance and child care.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Demographic Trends Are Behind Rising Healthcare Spending
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Consumer spending on healthcare and social assistance services won't slow in the coming years. Providers will continue to contend with the drop-offs in federal programs related to COVID-19, but demographic and economic forces will persist in driving healthcare consumption.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: The Pandemic's Long-Term Effects Are Emerging
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: This sector suffers from staffing shortages that predate the COVID-19 pandemic and became exacerbated by it. Labor shortages and employee burnout will continue challenging healthcare and social assistance providers. Healthcare providers across the sector will grapple with steeper costs for everything from medical supplies to pharmaceuticals and staff.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Tech Advances Will Reshape Healthcare Delivery
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Tech advances can potentially transform every aspect of healthcare and social assistance delivery, but navigating tech investments, evolving regulations and cybersecurity will pose challenges. Many healthcare and social assistance entities will adopt digital and telehealth tools to bridge the gap between urban and rural communities regarding healthcare access.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Financial Pressures Will Accelerate Consolidation Activity
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: The consolidation activity that defines the health sector will continue despite an economic environment of higher interest rates. Mounting healthcare costs and reimbursement cuts will incentivize smaller, independent healthcare providers to join larger health groups. Private equity investment will also be present in healthcare.

industry_definition: The Healthcare and Social Assistance sector is composed of enterprises that provide healthcare and social assistance for individuals in the United States, including hospitals, ambulatory service providers and nursing and residential care facilities. Social assistance also includes counselors and social workers, family and welfare services and natural disaster and emergency relief services.

positive_impact_factors: Federal funding for Medicare and Medicaid
negative_impact_factors: Number of people with private health insurance

opportunities: Federal funding for Medicare and Medicaid
threats: Number of people with private health insurance

key_trends: COVID-19 created unprecedented challenges for healthcare and social assistance providers. Staffing shortages and rising costs continue to impact providers and businesses.
Healthcare and social assistance providers are vital to older adults. As these people continue to age, their expanding and complex medical needs require various health and social services.

Healthcare providers received over $200.0 billion to ease pandemic-related financial and operational pressures. Since pandemic relief fizzled out, healthcare facilities have faced unprecedented financial strain.
Private insurers are the top payer to healthcare and social assistance entities. Providers of these services rely on private insurance reimbursements more than any other revenue source.
Hospitals are the largest providers in the health sector. These facilities are at the forefront in supporting public health.
Densely populated areas have higher healthcare usage. The Southeast is the most populated region, warranting a greater need for healthcare providers to meet residents' medical needs.

California has the most healthcare providers in the United States. The Golden State's expansive geographic area is home to a large population, which also allocates the most on personal healthcare spending nationally.
Healthcare and social assistance facilities are vital to public health. No substitutes exist for medical and social services, eliminating the factor of external competition.

Independent practices are the status quo in Healthcare and Social Assistance, despite consolidation. Consolidation changes healthcare delivery, but small, local service providers still define the sector.

market_segmentation.segment_description: Reimbursements from private payors include payments received from commercial health plans. Private insurers reimburse in-network providers for patient treatment; contract negotiations between payors and providers determine prices.
Government revenue sources include reimbursements from Medicaid and Medicare and grants or loans from federal or state agencies.
Medicaid is the second-largest payer of health services in the US – and these reimbursements make up a significantly larger share of sector revenue than Medicare reimbursements.
Out-of-pocket payments include payments by patients or family members for any care not covered by insurance. This includes deductibles, copayments and coinsurance.

tier_1_suppliers: Medical Device Manufacturing in the US
Medical Instrument & Supply Manufacturing in the US
Brand Name Pharmaceutical Manufacturing in the US
tier_2_suppliers: Heating & Air Conditioning Equipment Manufacturing in the US
Telecommunication Networking Equipment Manufacturing in the US
tier_1_buyers: Primary Care Doctors in the US
tier_2_buyers: Nursing Care Facilities in the US
Diagnostic & Medical Laboratories in the US

demand_determinants.determinant_title: Rising incomes and expanding insurance coverage
demand_determinants.determinant_description: Rising incomes and expanding insurance coverage have facilitated access to ambulatory healthcare service providers
The medical needs of older people also create demand for these providers, and adults of advanced age exhibit the highest consumption of healthcare services.

business_locations.location_description: More than one-quarter of the US population resides in the Southeast region. As a central population hub, this area houses many healthcare and social assistance providers to address the needs of its population.

The Mid-Atlantic's share of healthcare and social assistance providers mirrors its share of the population. Pennsylvania and New York contribute substantially to the share of establishments in this region.

The West's share of establishments aligns with its share of the US population. Yet, this region's share of providers is skewed by California's large population. California has the most healthcare and social assistance establishments in the US.

regulations_points.regulation_description: Healthcare facilities must furnish a Certificate of Need (CON) before any construction, renovation or major medical equipment acquisitions. A CON is a state-level regulatory mechanism for healthcare facilities that determines the public need for a new facility or service.

regulations_points.regulation_title: Antikickback Statute and Physician Self-Referral Laws
regulations_points.regulation_description: The federal Antikickback Statute prohibits the exchange of anything of value (financial incentives, low rents, excessive compensation) to incentivize the referral of business that's reimbursable by federal healthcare programs.

regulations_points.regulation_title: Health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act
regulations_points.regulation_description: All healthcare providers, including mental health and substance abuse clinics, must comply with the Health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act (HIPAA). The HIPAA criteria outline controls the use of patient health data by any healthcare provider that stores, shares or sends private patient data.

The Health Information Technology for Economic and Clinical Health (HITECH) Act mandates audits of healthcare providers to ensure they comply with HIPAA. The HITECH Act strengthens HIPAA by incentivizing providers to adopt electronic health records (EHR) and enforcing steeper penalties for noncompliance.

regulations_points.regulation_title: THE CENTERS FOR MEDICARE AND MEDICAID SERVICES PROVISIONS
regulations_points.regulation_description: The Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services (CMS) makes payments to participating healthcare providers under its Medicare and Medicaid programs based on various formulas. Federal law mandates that services hospitals render to Medicare and Medicaid patients meet professionally recognized standards.

The No Surprises Act (NSA) established new federal protections against surprise medical bills. The NSA bans surprise bills for most emergency services, nonemergency services from out-of-network providers at in-network facilities and services from out-of-network air ambulance service providers.

All healthcare industries are subject to various regulations and protocols to mitigate and monitor the spread of COVID-19 and its variants to prevent future outbreaks. Regulation regarding COVID-19 is determined and mandated by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC), the Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA) and the United States Department of Health and Human Services (HHS).

barriers_points.barrier_description: Healthcare and social assistance facilities can't provide services without trained and qualified staff. Ongoing critical staffing shortages and rising wages jeopardize providers' ability to acquire and retain staff.

basis_points.basis_title: No substitutes for medical and social services
basis_points.basis_description: Healthcare and social assistance facilities are vital to public health. No substitutes exist for medical and social services, eliminating the factor of external competition.

concentration_points.concentration_title: Fragmented Care is the Status Quo
concentration_points.concentration_description: Healthcare in the US has traditionally been fragmented, with small and independent providers offering personalized care to patients in local markets. Social assistance facilities provide primarily community-focused services with limited geographic scope.

concentration_points.concentration_title: The Regulatory Environment Keeps Concentration Low
concentration_points.concentration_description: While patient preference for these small, local practices has allowed these companies to continue operating, the sector has been experiencing a huge shift in its makeup in recent years.

concentration_points.concentration_title: Certificate of Need (CON) laws inhibit expansion
concentration_points.concentration_description: 36 states enforce CON laws. These laws require most healthcare facilities to demonstrate the public need for a facility expansion, service addition or medical equipment purchase before implementation. Consequently, they also create barriers to entry and expansion, impeding a company's ability to grow.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Healthcare Providers Confront the Exodus of Workers
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Labor shortages that characterize the health sector have been driving wage growth. The reasons for shortages are complex, with the exact extent of shortages varying between settings.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Financial Pressures Erode Profit for Healthcare and Social Assistance Providers
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Margins vary based on location, type of facility and payer mix. Healthcare providers receiving most of their revenue from commercial insurers enjoy higher profit.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: Healthcare and social assistance facilities can't provide services without trained and qualified staff. Ongoing critical staffing shortages and rising wages jeopardize providers' ability to acquire and retain staff.
Hospitals are central to healthcare delivery. Hospitals provide inpatient and outpatient medical services (diagnostic, treatment, etc.) via physicians, nursing and other health services.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_title: Drop in elective procedures and patient volumes following the onset of the pandemic
capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: Federal policies and billions of dollars in funding directed to hospitals alleviated the initial financial impact of revenue loss stemming from delays in elective care and drops in ER visits.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_title: Rapidly escalating costs for medical consumables, equipment and pharmaceuticals along with staffing shortages and employee burnout combine to create instability in the sector
capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: Financial pressures have accelerated hospitals' shift away from inpatient care. The popularity of telemedicine, an uptick in ambulatory surgery centers (ASCs) and new medical technologies facilitate the transition to outpatient care.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_title: Ambulatory Healthcare Services are an Alternative Care Site
capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: Ambulatory healthcare service providers deliver healthcare services to patients and don't provide inpatient services. The primary industries in this subsector include Specialist Doctors (62111b), Primary Care Doctors (62111a) and Dentists (62121).

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_title: Consolidation activity is occurring across this subsector
capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: The COVID-19 pandemic accelerated this trend, but rapidly growing demand and continual staffing shortages incentivize small providers to merge with larger health groups.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_title: Primary care and dental practices both demonstrate consolidation activity
capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: Smaller practices are joining larger health systems or private equity-backed groups to reap the benefits of negotiating power and economies of scale.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_title: NURSING AND RESIDENTIAL CARE FACILITIES ARE CRITICAL FOR PEOPLE OVER 65
capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: Nursing and residential care facilities provide residential care combined with either nursing, supervisory or medical care services. Key industries in this subsector include Nursing Care Facilities (62311) and Retirement Communities (62331).

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_title: SOCIAL ASSISTANCE PROVIDERS HAVE AN OUTSIZED ROLE
capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: Social assistance entities provide various types of assistance services directly to their clients. Industries in this subsector include Elderly and Disabled Services (62412), Day Care (62441) and Family Counseling and Crisis Intervention Services (62419).

volatility_points.volatility_title: HEALTHCARE SERVICES ARE VITAL TO PUBLIC HEALTH
volatility_points.volatility_description: Healthcare and social assistance facilities provide services that are essential to overall public health.

volatility_points.volatility_title: Healthcare Facilities' Financial Health Relies on Reimbursements
volatility_points.volatility_description: Reimbursements from public and private insurance programs influence healthcare providers' financial stability. Changes in these reimbursements (determined by various competing factors) can occur annually and produce significant consequences for healthcare and social assistance facilities.
The COVID-19 pandemic created unprecedented financial, workforce and supply chain challenges for the sector.

FAQs.question: How do you plan to effectively promote and differentiate our healthcare services in a highly competitive market?
FAQs.answer: As the healthcare industry becomes more crowded, standing out and attracting patients are vital for business growth

FAQs.question: How do you leverage digital marketing strategies to reach a wider audience and generate qualified leads for our healthcare services?
FAQs.answer: Utilizing online platforms is crucial for reaching potential patients and driving business. For example, social media platforms are powerful tools for connecting with patients, establishing thought leadership and fostering engagement

FAQs.question: How do you continuously assess and adapt our healthcare services to align with the changing needs and preferences of patients and the market?
FAQs.answer: Staying agile and responsive to dynamic healthcare landscapes is key to meeting patient expectations and remaining competitive.

FAQs.question: How does your company compete with other healthcare providers?
FAQs.answer: Operators in the sector compete primarily on the basis of price, accessibility, range of services offered, quality of care and reputation. Differentiation of services can also be a principal basis of competition.

FAQs.question: How do you assess and implement telehealth solutions to expand access, particularly in remote or underserved areas, and improve patient convenience?
FAQs.answer: Telehealth technology has become increasingly important in enhancing accessibility and patient-centered care delivery.

FAQs.question: What measures do you take to ensure compliance with industry regulations and protect patient data confidentiality and privacy when implementing new technologies?
FAQs.answer: Healthcare organizations must prioritize data security and compliance to maintain patient trust and adhere to legal requirements

FAQs.question: How do you ensure that your organization maintains compliance with all relevant healthcare regulations and guidelines?
FAQs.answer: Compliance with regulations is crucial to avoid legal penalties and ensure ethical and safe delivery of healthcare services.

FAQs.question: What steps do you take to regularly assess and address any compliance gaps or risks within your organization?
FAQs.answer: Ongoing monitoring and addressing compliance gaps is important to maintain the integrity of our operations and protect the well-being of patients.

FAQs.question: How do you ensure accurate and timely billing and reimbursement processes to optimize revenue cycle management?
FAQs.answer: Effective financial management is crucial for maintaining a healthy cash flow and maximizing revenue.

FAQs.question: What strategies do you employ to control costs and improve financial performance without compromising the quality of patient care?
FAQs.answer: Balancing financial sustainability with high-quality care delivery is essential for long-term business success in the healthcare industry.

FAQs.question: How do you think the nursing shortage affects the competitiveness and market position of your healthcare facility compared to similar organizations?
FAQs.answer: Healthcare facilities may struggle to attract and retain top talent, affecting their ability to offer specialized services or maintain high standards of care. This can reduce patient referrals and lower revenue, impacting the organization's market position. A nursing shortage may necessitate higher salaries and benefits to remain competitive, increasing operational costs and potentially affecting pricing strategies.

FAQs.question: How centrally located are you for your core customer base? Do you have strong local and community outreach?
FAQs.answer: Services should be geographically located in areas where they are required and easily accessed by the public.

FAQs.question: How do you think your organization's ability to access government subsidies and funding impacts your financial stability and capacity to provide quality healthcare services? How do you monitor funding opportunities?
FAQs.answer: An organization's ability to access government subsidies and funding impacts its financial stability. Monitoring funding opportunities is crucial because it ensures that the organization stays up-to-date on the latest programs, initiatives and financial support options made available by the government that can support their financial health.

FAQs.question: How does the number of people with private health insurance correlate with demand? As private insurance falls, how will you recover?
FAQs.answer: People covered by private health insurance typically use healthcare services more frequently, and their insurers often pay more for healthcare services than public insurers.

FAQs.question: Do you monitor changes in total health expenditure? Have you experienced heightened demand during periods of increased health expenditure?
FAQs.answer: Total health expenditure measures public and private spending on activities that, through the application of medical, paramedical and nursing knowledge and technology, promote health and prevent disease.

FAQs.question: How do fluctuations in federal funding for Medicare and Medicaid impact the reimbursement rates and revenue streams for your healthcare services? How does the federal funding level for Medicare and Medicaid affect your ability to provide quality patient care and maintain financial stability for your healthcare business?
FAQs.answer: Federal funding for Medicare and Medicaid significantly impacts healthcare businesses' financial stability and operations. Fluctuations in funding can directly influence reimbursement rates, which can substantially affect the revenue streams for healthcare providers. By understanding the impact of funding changes, employees can develop strategies to mitigate potential financial challenges.
